Award.AwardTitle: Machine Learning for Communication-Cognizant Smart Inverter Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Smart inverters interfacing solar panels, energy storage units, and electric vehicles to the main electric grid are an effective grid control mechanism to cope with the voltage fluctuations induced by solar generation in residential grids. However, selecting the power injections for hundreds of inverters in real time is a formidable task. To hit the sweet spot between cyber demanding optimization solutions and subpar local control, the proposed research develops novel algorithmic schemes for coordinating inverters based on control rules or policies trained through machine learning (ML). This program advances understanding of communication-limited decentralized control of residential electric grids and discovers novel uses of smart meter data, with immediate applicability to distribution systems and relevance to electric power utility practice. The expected benefits to industry are cutting-edge physics-aware ML solutions, advanced asset management, and value added for inverters, sensors, and grid communications. Enhancing grid controllability benefits society by enabling reliable integration of smart grid technologies, such as distributed solar generation, electric vehicles, and demand-response programs. Handling voltage excursions by inverters extends the lifetime of voltage regulators and capacitors, and postpones costly grid upgrades. The proposed research activities are integrated with educational and outreach objectives. The program reaches pre-college female students through hands-on learning activities on renewable energy sources and continues the PIs' outreach to undergraduate students through visits to residential communities and seminars. The findings will be integrated into the curricula of (under)-graduate courses on distribution grids and ML for energy systems, thus educating the upcoming power-engineering workforce on timely ML tools.

This project aspires to integrate machine learning (ML) models into optimal power flow (OPF) formulations to develop data-adaptive and communication-limited smart inverter control schemes in power distribution grids. This is achieved by accomplishing the ensuing tasks: i) devise algorithmic solutions to ensure ML modules comply with inverter specifications and feeder constraints; ii) capture the physical coupling across ML modules through approximate and exact AC power flow equations under both model-based and model-free setups; iii) put forth stochastic and chance-constrained ML-based OPF schemes to deal with the uncertainty of solar generation and loads; iv) design learning architectures that are centrally trained and implemented in a distributed manner on a tight communication budget to exploit big historical data but small real-time data feeds; and v) ensure dynamic stability and safety when ML modules are driven by states to close the loop. The outcome will be a comprehensive suite of ML-based inverter optimization solutions validated using real-world data on benchmark feeders. The proposed research pioneers the design of data-driven nonlinear inverter control policies at the nexus of power systems, ML, robust control, and stochastic optimization. The original and potentially transformative idea of learning inverter control rules through a stochastic constrained OPF is the permeating theme of this project. When OPF and local control schemes fail to adjust to time-varying grid conditions, the proposed ML-OPF solutions exploit creatively designed neural network topologies, as well as advances in kernel-based and reinforcement learning to operate effectively under the train-big/operate-small data paradigm. Building communication-aware inverter control policies will advance our knowledge on constrained learning over a physical or engineered system under a tight communication budget. Research tasks explore different ML tools; account for model-based and model-free setups; handle approximate and exact grid models; and consider varying communication capacities between the utility and inverters. Uniquely combining expertise on distribution grids, statistical learning, robust control, and reinforcement learning, this project goes beyond communication-limited inverter control to bandwidth-limited resource allocation problems and cyber-physical systems control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distributed energy resources (DERs), such as electric vehicles, photovoltaics, and batteries, are interfaced with the main grid through inverters. If properly coordinated, inverters have been advocated as an effective means to achieve energy management objectives in power distribution grids. Nonetheless, coordinating thousands of inverters in real-time can be computationally formidable. This project contributed machine learning (ML)-assisted methodologies to optimize and control DERs using a comprehensive suite of (de)-centralized schemes. The research outcomes are summarized next.

 

1) Learn-to-OPF: The learning-to-optimize paradigm aims to train a deep neural network (DNN) to learn the minimizer of an optimization problem once presented with the problem parameters as inputs. This concept is highly relevant in grid operation, where operators must adjust OPF decisions on a 5-min basis to account for variable grid conditions due to renewables. Training such DNNs, however, requires first solving many OPF instances to generate labels. Our creative idea was to train the DNN to match the minimizer as well as its partial derivatives with respect to the OPF inputs. Expanding upon results on sensitivity analysis of the OPF, we were able to compute the sensitivities of OPF minimizers and incorporate them into the training of the DNN. By doing so, we improved data efficiency by two orders of magnitude, thus expediting DNN training. The approach was tailored to various OPF formulations under linearized and exact grid models, including linear/quadratic, second-order cone, and semidefinite programs (SDP). As an alternative to DNNs, the approach was extended to Gaussian processes (GP), too.

 

2) Learn-and-OPF: The Learn-to-OPF paradigm described above first solves several OPF instances and then uses labeled OPF data to train a DNN. Rather than training DNNs to imitate already computed OPF solutions, we incorporated DNN-based control policies into the OPF. The proposed DNNs are trained in an unsupervised way, obviating the need for OPF labels. The weights are designed to minimize the objective function averaged across scenarios, subject to feeder constraints enforced on the average or in probability. The trained DNNs can be driven by partial, noisy, or proxy data of the grid conditions, which is critical in settings of limited observability. The approach was extended to linearized and exact grid models, and derivative-free and communication-limited variants.

 

3) Designing control rules via deep learning: The previous two schemes assumed DERs are centrally coordinated. Alternatively, DERs could operate autonomously based on control rules driven by local data at the expense of a degradation in performance. Our goal was to alleviate this degradation by optimally designing rules in a centralized fashion every few hours. The IEEE Standard 1547 suggests Volt/VAR rules, according to which inverters determine their reactive injections as functions of local voltages. Optimally designing the shape of Volt/VAR rules is a challenging problem as these rules introduce nonlinear dynamics, require bilinear optimization models, and lurk trade-offs between stability and steady-state performance. To avoid computationally intense mixed-integer formulations, our novel idea was to reformulate rule design as the task of training a DNN. The DNN takes grid conditions as inputs, uses rule parameters as weights, and computes equilibrium voltages as outputs. In the course of rule design, we also expanded on stability conditions and convergence rates for varius rules on single- and multi-phase feeders alike.

 

4) Stability of DNN-based control rules: The analysis of dynamical systems with DNNs in the loop is challenging due to the nonlinearity and uncertainty of the underlying model. Our proposed control-theoretic framework principally addressed this challenge by analytically decomposing a dynamical system model into a linear, nominal part and a nonlinear, uncertain perturbation with weak assumptions of its behaviors captured through integral quadratic constraints. We exploited unique structures of nonlinear activation functions of DNNs to bound its behavior through convex relaxation. The resulting condition can be verified by solving a semidefinite program parametrized by nominal system parameters, perturbation bounds, and DNN weights. 

 

The project outcomes in terms of broader impacts are summarized next.

 

1) This project funded partially or entirely six (6) graduate research assistants who now excel in academia and industry.

 

2) Dissemination: We communicated research findings to academia and industry through 35 events, including invited seminars, conference presentations, presentations to industry partners, and by organizing three panel sessions at flagship IEEE conferences.

 

3) Outreach to 850+ undergraduate students through more than eight activities:

 

a) Four seminars to undergraduate students on smart grids and career opportunities in STEM impacting 700 students, two of which targeted first-year female engineering students.

 

b) Hands-on lab activities with 80 middle-school students at the power systems lab related to transmission lines, transformers, motors, renewable energy, and efficiency.

 

c) Two discussion panels on career opportunities in STEM with 30 young high-school women from the US and abroad and 60 high school African American students.

 

d) Advancing courses: We integrated project findings into the courses ECE4424/CS4824: Machine Learning and ECE-5984: Power Distribution System Analysis.


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Vassilis Kekatos
